And the New York Times ran a story this year that suggested that in fact, a lot more eligible voters have been stricken from lists than new voters in some states.
Yeah, that's exactly right.

And is this evidence of some vast conspiracy either right or left wing?
Well, conspiracy may be too strong a word.

Now some methods of doing that are, of course, perfectly acceptable.
Every - each side in every election tries to register voters of its own party and voters likely to vote for its candidates.

Unfortunately, what we've seen throughout American history and continuing until the present day is sometimes parties try to manipulate voter registration lists or otherwise rig the system so as to make it more difficult for the other side's voters to get out there and vote.

On the one hand there's registration fraud, and on the other hand there's voter fraud.

Now registration fraud typically refers to phony registration forms being filled out on behalf of non-existent voters, and typically this happens when a voter registration group - and Acorn has been the example that's come up most often in this election - hires canvassers to go out and register voters for it, and sometimes those canvassers won't do the work they're being paid to do, will occasionally submit registration forms with names such as Mickey Mouse and Dick Tracy on them, and those get turned into Acorn or the other voter registration groups out there.
Now, Mickey Mouse's name may appear on a voter registration form but there's little or no evidence that Mickey Mouse has actually walked through the polling place door trying to vote.
That would be voter fraud if someone who is not eligible to vote attempted to vote or attempted to double vote using a fictitious name.
But voter fraud is extremely rare based on the evidence we have.
